div.p:
The extraordinary activity with which Alexander
Von Humboldt is gifted continues to manifest it-
self in intellectual labors which at his age are little
less than miraculous. A recent letter from him to
Hardinger, of Vienna, appears in a late number of
the Kœlnische Zeitung, and from which we trans-
late the following:

“All my collections of chrystals made in Ameri-
ca and Siberia were carefully gone over lately and
experimented upon by Rose and Rammelsberg,
and many new things have been discovered relative
to the component parts of trachytes, (a variety of
lava,) and their family dissemination. The differ-
ent families of this mineral are often found precise-
ly alike in the most remotely distant regions,
while again we find marked differences in an over-
lying strata. Thirty four sheets of the last part of
my Kosmos are already printed. I hope to con-
clude the work with this year, and trust that it will
not escape your attention.”

There can be no question that the appearance of
a new volume of Kosmos will excite not a little at-
tention in the scientific world. When we remem-
ber that this is the work of one well nigh a cente-
narian, and that we have during the past year pub-
lished more than one extract from his letters, indi-
cating the most genial flow of spirits, the most un-
tiring industry, and all the enthusiasm for science
which could be expected in the youngest devotee,
we cannot but admit that a strong confirmation is
added by the instance of Von Humboldt to the
theories of those philosophers who maintain that
intellectual pursuits, when born out by easy circum-
stances, far from wearing life away, actually extend
its term.
